chapterTitle: Introduction to Valuation:The Time Value of Money

columns.text: Here we need to compare the effect of Simple Interest against Compounding Interest. We are offered the choice between two bank accounts with different interest conditions and see the difference at the end of eight years.

We know the following values:


| | | 
|--|--| 
| Initial Deposit|$7,500 | 
| First City Bank Interest rate | 9%| 
| Second City Bank Interest rate | 9%| 
|Years|8|

The first option is First City Bank which offers an account that produces Simple Interest. So we need to calculate the Future Value (FV) of our Present Value (PV) or initial deposit if we account for simple interest.

**Simple interest** means that there is no reinvestment of the interest generated. Meaning that interest payments will be the same every period. 

$$\begin{aligned}
FV &= PV + (PV \cdot r \cdot t)\\
&= \$7,500 + (\$7,500 \cdot 9\% \cdot 8) \\
&= \boxed{\$12,900}

\end{aligned}$$

In eight years we would have **$12,900** in our First City Bank account.

Now the second option is Second City Bank which offers an account that produces Compound Interest. So we need to calculate the Future Value (FV) of our Present Value (PV) or initial deposit if we account for the compounding effect.

**Compound interest** means that every payment of interest will be reinvested into the principal value. Meaning that every period the interest payment will be higher than the previous one.  

$$\begin{aligned}
FV &= PV\cdot(1+ r)^ t\\
&= \$7,500 \cdot (1 +0.09)^ 8\\
&= \boxed{\$14,944.22}

\end{aligned}$$

In eight years we would have **$14,944.22** in our Second City Bank account.

To conclude we need to know how much more we would have in the Second City Bank account than in the First Bank account.

$$\$14,944.22 - \$12,900 = \boxed{\$2,044.22}$$

We would have **$2,044.22** more thanks to the compounding effect of the Second City Bank.
